reviewText: ONE STEP BEYOND was the pioneer TV show in the supernatural genre. This half-hour ABC TV series (first broadcast on Jan 20th, 1959) was based on purportedly true stories. Occasionally an episode featured the person who actually experienced a paranormal event (The Peter Hurkas Story, for example). Pure fantasy, fiction and irony would later be employed to great success by Rod Serling's TWILIGHT ZONE. Because ONE STEP BEYOND dealt with more genuine (and therefore less "mind-boggling") subject matter, it was quickly surpassed in popularity by the Serling show. The series met a premature end in June of 1961, but not before 97 episodes had aired.The MILL CREEK ENTERTAINMENT box set of VERY BEST OF ONE STEP BEYOND presents 50 episodes encompassing all three years of this program's network run. Twenty-four season two episodes, 14 season three and 12 from the first abbreviated year make up the collection.Episode ratings were obtained from a TV show archive website. The numbers may be somewhat inflated, for based on five of these programs that have polling data at a much larger film resource site, the average rating is only 5.7 on a 1 to 10 scale. The TV show site's averaged-out score for all 50 programs in this package is: 9.1.The following alphabetized list includes poll results for each show, episode number, original date of broadcast and principal actors involved.(7.3) (#15) The Aerialist (2/28/59) - Roy Baker/Mike Connors(9.4) (#63) Anniversary Of A Murder (9/27/60) - Harry Townes/Amzie Strickland(9.9) (#25) Brainwave (10/6/59) - Whit Bissell/Raymond Bailey(9.7) (#19) The Captain's Guests (5/26/59) - Felix Locher/Robert Webber(10.) (#49) The Clown (3/22/60) - John Close/Yvette Mimieux/Mickey Shaughnessy (both in support)(9.2) (-#4) The Dark Room (2/10/59) - Cloris Leachman/Ann Codee(6.5) (#78) Dead Man's Tale (1/17/61) - Lonny Chapman/Jean Engstrom(7.9) (-#9) The Dead Part Of The House (3/17/59) - Phillip Abbott/Mimi Gibson(9.4) (#33) Dead Ringer (12/1/59) - Norma Crane/Grant Williams(7.5) (#54) Delia (5/3/60) - Barbara Lord/Murray Matheson(9.6) (#23) Delusion (9/15/59) - George Mitchell/Norman Lloyd/Suzanne Pleshette(9.1) (#11) The Devil's Laughter (3/31/59) - Alfred Ryder/Alma Lawton(9.5) (#26) Doomsday (10/13/59) - Fintan Meyler/Patrick O'Moore(7.2) (-#7) The Dream (3/3/59) - Jack Lynn/Charles Horvath(8.5) (#39) Earthquake (1/12/60) - David Opatoshu/Elvira Curci(6.4) (#20) Echo (6/2/59) - Ross Martin/Leslie Barrett/Edmund Glover(9.5) (#76) The Executioner (1/3/61) - Crahan Denton/Tom Middleton(9.6) (#48) The Explorer (3/15/60) - Rudolph Anders/Edith Evanson/Bert Convy (in support)(8.5) (#31) Forked Lightning (11/17/59) - Frank Maxwell/Candy Moore(9.3) (#21) Front Runner (6/9/59) - Walter Burke/Ben Cooper(9.8) (#56) Gypsy (5/17/60) - Johnny Seven/John Kellogg/Robert Blake (in support)(9.7) (#37) The Hand (12/29/59) - Robert Loggia/Miriam Colon(9.8) (#50) I Saw You Tomorrow (4/5/60) - Francis Bethencourt/Narda Onyx(10.) reviewText: "One Step Beyond" was an anthology television series that broadcast on ABC from 1959 to 1961, airing 9 months prior to "The Twilight Zone". It was created by Merwin Gerard, and hosted by John Newland. Similar to "The Twilight Zone" yet different as the stories in this anthology are said to be based on true events. "One Step Beyond" dealt with all kinds of subjects(such as mind-altering drugs, premonition of death, astral projection, ghosts & more). The show was remade in the 70s as "The Next Step Beyond" with John Newland returning as the host & ran for one season. The show itself features alot of well-known actors & actresses these days(such as Robert Blake, Elizabeth Montgomery, Charles Bronson, and Christopher Lee). This collection has 50 of the 96 episodes in total, with the 'Very Best' episodes of the series. I, myself, was not familiar with the series til I came across this collection of episodes in a bargain bin at my local Wal-Mart shopping center. I bought it due to it's similarity to "The Twilight Zone", a show I love watching. In all honesty, I find "One Step Beyond" to be the better show due to the fact that it dealt with true events. We all know, though, that "The Twilight Zone" won the hearts of the spectators.If you're a big fan of "The Twilight Zone" or anthology shows in general(like "Thriller", "Chillers", "Urban Gothic" or "The Ray Bradbury Theater"); you ought to give "One Step Beyond" a shot.  For this collection, you've got more than half of all the episodes that aired with only 46 more to find and you won't find it at a better price.
summary: The Very Best of One Step Beyond.........

reviewText: I own several "classic era" TV DVD boxed sets, so I am accustomed to accepting less than perfect sound and video quality in order to have collections of high-quality drama and comedy from the past. Some have called this show a forerunner of "The Twilight Zone", but that is not exactly true. Each segment in this series was based on paranormal events or situations that defied logical explanation. In that sense, this show was much more similar in style to "The X-Files", except without the long story arcs. "The Twilight Zone" episodes, on the other hand, were pure fiction, often written to explore some current social issue that, due to the conventions of the times, would have been impossible to talk about in a straightforward manner without igniting a controversy.I first saw this series in the 1980's when it was running on the then-new "Nick at Nite", and I was fascinated by it. When this DVD set came out, I jumped at the opportunity. This collection has about half of the 97 episodes that were filmed, and that is probably all that is in existence due to the expired copyright and the neglect the original footage probably fell into. The one episode I really missed seeing in the set was "Father Image". This is one of the episodes I saw on "Nick at Nite" years ago, and concerned a man whose father has left him some property, including an old boarded-up burlesque house. Nobody can understand why he never sold the place, until an accident causes the son to see images from his dead father's life that include his murder of a girl he was having an affair with and the disposal of her body in the burlesque house, which he closed shortly after the murder and left abandoned. The son finds the body, and would have some explaining to do to the police if it was not obvious that the girl had died years before the son was born. The episode dealt with the issue of children inheriting memories from their parents. I just mention this episode as an example, since I don't want to give away anything from the episodes that are actually in this boxed set.You'll notice lots of guest appearances by not-yet famous stars such as Elizabeth Montgomery, Charles Bronson, Jack Lord, Warren Beatty, and Pernell Roberts. I highly recommend it.
summary: A great DVD set in spite of the quality issues

reviewText: ...was One Step Beyond, hands down. I first saw this show as a kid and it scared the bejesus out of me. It must be a psychological thing but old black-and-white films have an eerieness that is lost on color film, and to turn up the chill factor even more was that spooky Harry Lubin score that usually played in the background just at the climax of a scary scene.This show didn't have to rely on a lot of special effects to scare a person witless since most of the terror came from the fact that all of the episodes were based on true stories. Also, John Newland did a splendid job setting up the show and lended, as others here have noted, a sense of creepiness to the proceedings.BTW, you'll recognize many an actor and actress in these shows, many before they became famous. So sit back, prop your feet up, and break out the popcorn. Just don't turn off the lights!
summary: One Of The Scariest Shows On Television
Title: N/A

reviewText: John Newland was as creepy as Rod Serling was strange. That's the only comparison worthy between these two shows. So often comparisons spring forth between Zone and Step, but they are neither justified, nor accurate.Zone is generally a charachter study of people in the most perplexing of situations that could never take place in the real world.Step is a study of unexplainable events that were documented by the people the events affected, then dramatized by actors.Step was not only enormously entertaining to watch, it was smart in execution. Newland not only hosts, but also directs many episodes. Anyone who is a fan of the genre of the unexplained should definitely take a look at this incredible show.Show rating: 5 stars, DVD transfer: 3 stars, packaging: 2 stars (12 DVD's in regular size Amaray cases in a flimsy posterboard thickness paper box sleeve??! Come on guys, we collectors deserve a smarter, more space saving and quality package.)Overall rating: 4 stars
summary: Take this One Step Beyond...

reviewText: In my quest for all things loved as a child, I was thrilled to find this set of episodes of one of my Sunday morning shows that I loved. At 5 in the morning on Sundays this show would run two episodes and then an hour of the Three Stooges would come on, so every Sunday at 5:00 a.m. I was plunged into the world of the supernatural for one hour and then given an hour of laughs before everyone got up and ready for Church. The stories were all "documented" as true(at least that is what they told us) and had the goose-bump factor well in place. Most were very good and all featured some well known faces( Charles Bronson, Robert Blake, even William Shatner) and the air of believeability about them.The transfers are another matter, they never looked that great back then , but little if any care has been given to clean these up and the constant hum can be madding. I have ordered some of the other sets and hope they are better, but still I did enjoy the stories, but beware!
summary: 5 star stories(most of the time anyway), but 1 star transfers= 2 stars

reviewText: I remember this show from TV and I LOVED it!  There are 4 DVDs of 50 digitally remastered complete episodes, 12/13 per disc.  The show was on about the same time period as the popular "Twilight Zone" series, but instead of being fictionalized writing, these were dramatizations, said to be based on real life supernatural stories. Incidents included happenings involving precognition, spirits, disappearances, and fantastic creatures.  It's also noteworthy to see some very young and later famous actors and actresses in the series, such as Warren Beatty, Charles Bronson, Mike Connors, Patrick Macnee (The Avengers), Pernell Roberts (Adam/Bonanza), Cloris Leachman, Suzanne Pleshette, and others you will recognize when you see their faces. I think the show host's name was John Newland and he is spooky. You have the option of playing each disc straight through or selecting an individual episode from a list of what's on the disc.  Each disk also lists the episodes on it's face that are on that disc.  Episodes last about 20 minutes each.  The other 10 minutes in the show, when it was on TV, went for commercials."Alcoa presents:  One Step Beyond."Disc 1 begins with "Night of April 14th", a story about a young lady who has terrifying nightmares of being on a sinking ship and drowning, not being able to find her fiancée in the dark, then her fiancée buys tickets for their honeymoon on the unsinkable R.M.S.Titanic. She continues having the nightmares, feeling the iciness of the water, seeing the people drowning, hearing their screams, seeing a huge ship and even seeing the word "Titanic" on the side of the ship.  Her mother and fiancée tell her she has an overactive imagination, and similar dismissing comments.  So, off they go on the maiden voyage of the Titanic.  After 6 days of perfect happiness, guess what happens?  That night, many others, from many different places, claimed to have dark premonitions of the Titanic sinking, but, not to worry; everyone knew the Titanic was UNSINKABLE!  There was also a book, published some years before, about a very similar unsinkable ship which sank, called "The Titan.""Make Me Not A Witch" is on Disc 2, a story about Amy, a 12-year old farm girl, who HEARS what her mother is THINKING and it scares the heck out of her mother.  Then her father calls her a witch and scares her into keeping her mouth shut.  He said she has the devil inside her.  Amy goes to church, crying and praying to God to make her NOT a witch; she is terrified!  A priest tells her she is not a witch and he will protect her.  He later asks her to read an old man's mind (because he cannot speak) to save the lives of 2 children."Earthquake" is also on Disc 2, taking place on April 17, 1906 in San Francisco.  Bellhop Perkins, while working, envisions the big quake before it happens and passes out on the floor.  A little later, he envisions the earthquake again.  He tries to warn people but no one believes him.  The hotel manager locks Perkins in his room and then fires him, accusing him of stealing whisky and getting drunk.  Perkins insists the quake will happen at 5:13 because he envisioned the time on the clock, but the manager says it's 5:22 now, so Perkins must be drunk.  Wanna guess what happens?  By the way, he foresaw 5:13 the next morning (not 5:13 that night)."The Storm," from disc 3, begins in Sierra Madre and is about a painting called "La Tormenta/The Storm" that was JUST painted by a man who died several years BEFORE it was painted.OK.  That's enough.  You're on your own now.  These are cool stories, in black and white.  (Yes, young whippersnappers, there WAS black and white TV before color came about.)  I used to watch this show faithfully and I loved it but had forgotten how good it really was.  Just a side note:  Seems like more and more people are becoming interested in the supernatural nowadays.  Time to revive this show.
summary: Alcoa Presents:  One Step Beyond!

reviewText: By chance, I just saw this "Very Best Of One Step Beyond"-50 episode set at a local store. Before deciding to purchase it, I came home to read some reviews of this set first. As usual, most people complained of the poor transfers to DVD, which I wasn't really surprised to hear. A while back, I purchased that 10 DVD boxed set that has about 4 episodes on each disc, and although these transfers weren't great either, I would have still been happy with the set...except for one thing. I later purchased the 2-DVD set with 12 episodes that was released in 2003, and discovered that a few, if not all of the episodes here were MUCH better prints and seemed to be completely un-edited! The episode that this was most noticable on was "Anniversary Of A Murder", one of the best in the series! The print from the 10 DVD boxed set has a BIG chunk of the beginning completely missing from the episode, and it really loses a lot of it's dramatic impact because of it! The 10 DVD boxed set is good mainly for the huge number of episodes it contains, but the 2-DVD set with only 12 episodes appears to be of much better quality. My question here is this: On the 50 episode set, "The Very Best of One Step Beyond", are the episodes edited or are they complete? The box claims they are complete episodes but I've seen these mistakes printed on boxes before! Even though this "Very Best Of" set contains ALL the same episodes from my 10-DVD boxed set, I would still purchase it IF I knew they were completely un-cut! Does anyone know?
summary: Can anyone answer this question?...

reviewText: This "One Step Beyond" DVD compilation brings together slightly more than half of the total episodes from the series, on four well-formatted disks. As other reviewers have noted, the episodes are in terrible shape, full of scratches, gaps and blips. It seems unlikely at this point, alas, that anyone will take the trouble to restore them. "One Step Beyond," in any case, always seemed to belong to the very early days of television; shot on cheap videotape, the series never had the production gloss of "The Twilight Zone" or "Alfred Hitchcock Presents." (Watching multiple episodes of "One Step Beyond," the series' low budget becomes apparent in how often the same sets were used.) It was a shock for me, in fact, to find out that "One Step Beyond" premiered only a few months before "The Twilight Zone;" I had always assumed it dated from the very early '50s. In a way, however, the wavering, flickering images add to the eerieness of the show, making the performers seem like ghosts captured during a seance.Unlike "The Twilight Zone," "One Step Beyond" always dealt with the paranormal, and always insisted that all its stories were based on fact. (In an interview shortly before his death, John Newland said all the stories used on the show had either written or anecdotal evidence of their truth.) The best episodes of "One Step Beyond" were those that either captured the audience with a last-second, throat-catching surprise (I particularly liked the one about the London housewife and her presumably imaginary lover) or that had particularly fine performances. In the interview, Newland said his favorite performance in the entire series was that of the character actor Alfred Ryder, playing a condemned man who grows progressively more arrogant as his executioners fail, again and again, to hang him. That indeed was a fine performance, but there were others. I particularly loved the performances of the very young Cloris Leachman and Jean Renoir favorite Marcel Dalio in a tale of ghostly doings in provincial France, and also of Norman Lloyd as a wormy little psychic and the very young Suzanne Pleshette as the tart whose future he foresees. There are interesting combinations of actors throughout the series, such as the episode featuring Joan Fontaine and the very young Warren Beatty (who, it is apparent, was still learning his craft). There also are performances that have taken on an unintentionally creepy frisson (such as Robert Blake as a prison inmate, five years before "In Cold Blood" and 45 years before his own murder trial).Every series has its Achilles heel. "The Twilight Zone" always faltered when it tried to be funny, and "One Step Beyond" had a sentimental streak that doesn't play well with contemporary audiences. (One episode, featuring Mickey Shaughnessy as a mute clown and Yvette Mimieux as a jealous man's child bride, is particularly icky.)The personality who tied "One Step Beyond" together was Newland, who appeared in (and directed) every episode, sometimes as the omniscient narrator and sometimes as a "John Newland" character who interpreted for the other characters the inexplicable events they had just lived through. An elegant, ironic yet soothing presence, Newland was the perfect host for the series and deserves to be much better remembered than he is today. (His interview revealed him as a thoroughly pleasant, thoughtful man.) In any case, this "One Step Beyond" compilation pays ample testimony to his artistry, and should prove rewarding to all fans of the creepy, eerie, and bizarre on TV.
summary: A delightfully eerie blast from the past.

reviewText: What an amazing bargain this set is. 50 episodes of great supernatural drama with some recognisable faces amongst the cast. Again, as with many of these public domain releases of tv shows, the picture quality is not the best but is perfectly watchable, and in some episodes, very good. What is great to see in these shows is the intensity of some of the acting. Modern actors may be more naturalistic but sometimes I miss the more 'dramatic' acting of the old shows, and 'One Step Beyond' is a great showcase for these talented actors. Buy this now for many hours of great entertainment.
summary: Classic tv

reviewText: Better than The Twilight Zone (and other similar series) which was all fiction. One Step Beyond is all based on fact, which makes it all the more interesting and in some cases, disturbing. This is a very well presented, value for money set, packaged economically in that you don't get loads of unnecessary packaging, but just a straightforward dvd case with all the discs safely fixed on their individual holders. Also contains some foam squares to protect the discs from maybe getting scratched, which is a further nice touch on the part of the manufacturer.Some very good stories, very absorbing to watch and with some wellknown names appearing too. Vague recollections of childhood watching and being fascinated by the stories. There are fifty of them on here, which is excellent value for money. It doesn't look as though the picture quality has been cleaned up much, if at all, but for the price and otherwise all round good quality of the packaging, I don't think anyone can complain about that! And truth be told, the picture quality is not at all bad and certainly no worse than anyone should expect given the time scale involved.
summary: Well worth the money. And the stories are based on truth.

reviewerName: reluctantpopstar "Like a movie? Make a movie"
reviewText: Well, allow me to explode a little myth.  The reason these episodes are in such "low quality" is not because the company "doesn't care about the customer" or some such shallow gripe.  The reason these DVD discs are mastered from somewhat bad quality 16 mm film prints is that this series is in the PUBLIC DOMAIN.  Almost everything released by Delta is a Public Domain film or TV show.  That means  (usually) that the copyright holder has gone bankrupt and did not renew the copyright, causing the content to enter the public domain  (a very difficult and complicated topic, look at [...] for more information).Anyway, sometimes this means that the negatives or "masters" are not even available.  They may have been misplaced in storage, are held in some tight-fisted collector's vault, or simply thrown in the garbage by someone who did not know what exactly they had.  In such a case, the only copies left are film prints floating around in the hands of various collectors.  This is probably also the reason why not all of the episodes have been released: the releasing company could only lay their hands on a certain number of 16 mm film prints out of the entire series.  Fortunately, the fact that these episodes are in the Public Domain means that we, the public, can legally see them, since a company (or anyone else) can legally duplicate and sell them.  So don't cry or moan about the low quality here: we're probably lucky we've got these episodes to view at all.  As far as the dramatic content, there's plenty here for fans of The Twlight Zone and other similar shows, and I can recommend them highly on that basis with no qualms or modifiers whatsoever.  Great stuff out of the past.
summary: The reason for quality issues
Title: N/A

reviewText: Can't some company, somewhere give "One Step Beyond" the respect it deserves? I have long admired this fantastic, bizarre anthology series. I remember watching it as a kid first run on television and being scared to death."Your tour guide into the unknown" John Newland is enough to scare the pants off of anybody, especially the way he wanders through a lot of the episodes. He's usually not content to just show up at the beginning like Rod Serling. While Serling presented himself as the sardonic writer/host of "The Twilight Zone," Newland as director/host of "One Step Beyond" is presented with all the charm of a funeral director who has just heard about a 25 car pile-up on the interstate. He's just plain creepy.The episodes presented here are, for the most part, great. It's the prints for most of the episodes that are lousy. Most are too dark and are full of scratches and specks of dirt. But the worst sin of all is that many are so choppy from splices that it ruins a lot of the dialogue, and dialogue is an important element in the enjoyment (and sometimes understanding) of "One Step Beyond." These prints look like worn-out 16mm films found in the backroom of some television station.Why can't some company out there give the same treatment to "One Step Beyond" that was done a few years ago with "The Twilight Zone"? In other words, clean up the picture and the sound, digitally remaster each episode, or, better yet, find the original negatives and work from those. Let's see this "journey into the unknown" the way it was meant to be. Geez, it that asking too much?
summary: "One Step Beyond" deserves much better

reviewText: John Newland's One Step Beyond was played at about the same time as Rod's Twilight Zone.  Both are comparable in many ways: both use "little known" stars who later went onto fame and fortune.  Charles BronsonCharles Bronson: The 95 Films and the 156 Television Appearancesplays a fighter who sees a ghost. Legend says whoever sees this ghost soon dies.  Four people see him!  Uh oh!  Pregnant lady sees a plane crash into her house days before it actually happens.  But everything will be all right.  Newland shakes his head and shrugs "No, everything will  not be all right". I noted many actors who went on to 60s TV shows or films.  One could compare this series to Alfred Hitchcock Presents, another fun anthology series.In the early shows he will actually briefly interview the actual people who were dramatized in the stories but these seem to stop happening with later programs.Quality is not that great, with scratches and pops that could easily be cleaned up with today's digital technology.  Awesome black & white.A list of episodes have already been listed here by better reviewers than I.  Do watch this -- have a One Step Beyond marathon some weekend.If Amazon will allow it, please see the following link for the episodes of each plus a summary of each story:[...]To see:Alfred Hitchcock Presents - Season OneTwilight Zone: The Complete Definitive CollectionOne Step Beyond 4-DVD Pack

reviewText: It is fun to look at the sets of the 1950s, and being in black and white gives an interesting perspective.  The subject of unexplained phenomena in a show during the 1950s is heartening since even now people still dismiss such occurrences.  I personally didn't know Boris Karloff tried his hand at hosting a tv show plus playing a role in all the episodes in The Veil.  John Newland does a good job of easing the viewer into each episode of One Step Beyond.
summary: forerunners to In Search Of and The Nightstalker
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'll start off by saying, I have never heard of One Step Beyond. It was way before my time. I read the reviews and became curious! So I bought the 12 DVD Box Set. I loved it!  John Newland as narrator awesome! He takes actual cases of paranormal experiences,past lives,esp,apparitions, out-of-body experiences and make dramatizations out of them. A few of my favorites:(1)Tonight at 12:17-A pregnant woman has erie premonitions about a plane crash. (2)The Peter Hurkos Story pt.1-Based on his life story.  How he discovered his psychic abilities. (3) The Peter Hurkos Story pt.2-Peter tracks down a killer,using his psychic abilities. (4)Person Unknown-An artist uses the death mask of a victim to set a man free.  Just to mention a few. I have to agree with one reviewer it's cheaper if you buy the volumes seperately.  I don't know why.  The box set is a little pricey,but it's well worth it! DVD transfer very good.Sound quality very good.I am a twilight zone fan,but twilght zone can't compare to one step beyond!  I can see where twilight zone got alot of their ideas.  I want to get all  episodes!!  I've already ordered One step Beyond-Collection 1.  I recommend you either by one step beyond seperately or the box set!  You won't be disappointed!
summary: Go One Step Beyond

reviewText: I read all the reviews before posting mine, which I generally do. I don't like rehashing things that have already been beaten to death, and I won't do so here.There are a few things I wanted to address that have been brought up by other reviewers. One is the quality of the DVDs. Obviously, this is a very subjective issue. Those who are sticklers for pristine picture quality and remastered video and sound will be disappointed and will likely give this release a fairly low grade. Those who understand that this is a program that is almost 50 years old, likely has no excellent quality masters to speak of and is also priced very modestly will likely tell you that it is a great value. I fall into the latter category. With so many boxed sets of old television shows, that are very inexpensive, flooding the market nowadays, we should be growing accustomed to the fact that they have not been remastered and cleaned up. The low price should be our first tipoff of that. Those who expect very high quality for this kind of price are foolish, IMO. The fact is that the quality of these DVDs is really not that bad at all. Some people complained of a humming sound, but I must admit that I did not notice this on the first 3 DVDs I have played thus far. Maybe I am hard of hearing, but I thought they sounded decent. They have also all played just fine on my DVD player, which is not a top-of-the-line model. Others have said certain episodes don't play on their machines. I can't comment on that, as mine have all played fine.Another thing I wanted to comment on was the style and delivery of the show's host, John Newland. He is delightfully macabre and I always got a kick out of how he tells us about the chilling, bizarre and sometimes frightening tale to come with a smile on his face. The dichotomy is not lost on me and I find it amusing. I like Newland very much.The last thing I wanted to comment on is the fact that so many reviewers have noted that the stories on One Step Beyond are 'true' and 'based on facts'. Yes, it's true that Mr. Newland never hesitates to inform us that these tales are based upon actual incidents that were reported by the people involved, and that they were never 'disproved'. Well, I doubt the incidents were investigated 'in depth' in order to ascertain their 'truth'. Saying that something has never been 'disproved' is not the same as saying it is true. As someone who has had an experience that was made into a feature film, I can tell you from personal experience that when a studio says a movie is 'based on a true story', what they do in most cases is to take an event that actually happened and weave a whole new plot around it. It is still, however, 'based' on a true story. People tend to want to believe it is true so to them, it is. I'm certainly not trying to rain on anyone's parade, it's just that I'm a bit more skeptical that all these stories are 'true'. I can believe they were reported to be true by those involved, but the fact that they were never 'disproved' does little to fuel my imagination into believing they really happened that way. But then, I'm crazy, I know....That said, this was, indeed, a fun and entertaining show, and it is fun to see some familiar faces in starring roles. I don't think it was as good as The Twilight Zone, but it was still a fine program, and this box set is well worth the minimal cost.Peace.
summary: Recommended - a bargain
